content.webTitle: King aims for new deal at Spurs

fields.headline: King aims for new deal at Spurs
fields.bodyText: The Tottenham captain Ledley King has said he is happy to pledge his long-term future to the club now that things were "going in the right direction". The England World Cup hopeful, who scored in the north London derby on Saturday, is contracted to Spurs until 2008, a deal which he agreed only last summer. However, after a string of impressive displays for club and country, including as a holding midfielder for England in the World Cup qualifier against Poland, the 24-year-old is hoping for a new offer. His advisers are in negotiations over improved terms, reported to be in the region of £50,000 a week, which would bring King in line with Spurs' other top earners such as Edgar Davids. "It's between my agent and the club. I am just letting them get on with it and concentrating on my football. I've always said that, if we are going in the right direction, I haven't got a problem." King added: "The lads have given us an indication of what we are capable of. We have a young squad and we have to keep going. The Champions League would be a bonus. You take it one game at a time and see where we can get."
